results.title: Spring Culture Fell to Virus. In Oregon, Summer Theater Now Succumbs.
results.abstract: As nonprofits around the country cancel all spring programs, the Oregon Shakespeare Festival halts performances through Labor Day, and will lay off 80 percent of its staff.

multimedia.caption: The festival will postpone live productions until after Labor Day. Its flagship stage is the outdoor Allen Elizabethan Theater, which seats up to 1,200 people.
multimedia.copyright: Kim Budd via Oregon Shakespeare Festival

results.title: Krzysztof Penderecki, Polish Composer With Cinematic Flair, Dies at 86
results.abstract: Mr. Penderecki's modernist compositions turned up in films like
and influenced a generation of edgy rock musicians.

multimedia.caption: Krzysztof Penderecki conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra of Yale at Carnegie Hall in 2010. In addition to his work as a composer, he had a lucrative career as conductor of the Krakow Symphony and as a guest conductor abroad.

results.title: Mike Longo, Jazz Pianist, Composer and Educator, Dies at 83
results.abstract: Best known for his long association with Dizzy Gillespie, Mr. Longo, who died of the coronavirus, also led a big band and promoted the work of other musicians.

multimedia.caption: Mike Longo performing with the Dizzy Gillespie Big Band at the Tivoli Concert Hall in Copenhagen in 1968. Mr. Longo's association with Gillespie began in 1966 and endured until shortly before Gillespie's death in 1993.

results.title: Stuart Gordon, Whose Films Reanimated Horror, Dies at 72
results.abstract: His low-budget movies, notably the cult favorite
combined grisly body horror with a mordant sense of humor.

multimedia.caption: The director Stuart Gordon in 2008. Celebrated for his lavishly lurid horror movies, he was also known for theater work that, like his films, often straddled the line between the serious and the hilarious.

results.title: Swiss Museum Settles Claim Over Art Trove Acquired in Nazi Era
results.abstract: The Kunstmuseum in Basel agreed to pay the heirs of a Berlin collector for 200 works he sold as he fled German persecution of Jews.

multimedia.caption: The Kunstmuseum in Basel has reversed its position and will now pay to retain an art collection sold by a Jewish museum director as he fled the Nazis.
